title: Hello, Putin! A flying bear that swept the Internet
teaser: The absurdity of Russia's lumbering mascot as an airport logo is irresistible. Stay weird, Khabarovsk.
contentencoded:
A flying bear has swept across the Russian Internet from the far eastern city of Khabarovsk, which is right on the border with China. The image is supposedly the new logo for the airport there.

RuNet, as Russia's online world is called, immediately seized upon the ... interesting image. The bear, of course, has been Russia's unofficial national avatar since time immemorial. But as Khabarovsk's new airport logo — assuming it's real — strives to take the lumbering mascot to new heights, its absurdity has been irresistible. 

Obviously. pic.twitter.com/jmslegE944

— Kevin Rothrock (@KevinRothrock) January 28, 2015

Другие варианты лого для #Хабаровск #аэропорт pic.twitter.com/0ZBQkaAswm

— Диванный Политолог (@_Aquarelle) January 28, 2015

The site Weird Russia has compiled several other iterations. As it notes, the logo only came to light in publicity materials related to an upcoming sports competition in Khabarovsk: The 2015 Bandy World Championship, which starts Feb. 1st, featuring teams from as far as Somalia, Latvia, and Mongolia (actually, Mongolia's capital is a [mere] 1300 miles from Khabarovsk, not far at all by standards of Russia's Far East). 

Bandy, the New York Times tells us, is a sport that predates hockey by 200 years. In Khabarovsk, at least, the sport's logo features a bear on a sled.

Or something. Not really sure what's going on with *that* bear either. As for the airport's ostensible logo, it's now nowhere to be found on the championship's site. The site Regional News of Russia notes drily that in 2013, local authorities offered a tender of 800-thousand rubles (about $23,000 at the time) for a new airport logo design, but "after a while this order disappeared from the public procurement site." Airport authorities are denying this is their planned logo. But RuNet is driving the online conversation.

The Khabarovsk Airport Logo Is a Viral Sensation. It's Also a Flying Bear. http://t.co/5IbYxp5gs6 pic.twitter.com/FlKH0iHtw2

— RuNet Echo (@runetecho) January 28, 2015

I traveled once to Khabarovsk in 2002 and was so jet-lagged from the seven-hour difference with Moscow that I don't recall that airport at all. I left the city by train, and at the station was told I needed a special travel document as a foreigner. I treasure it still.

Khabarovsk has changed, of course, since the days when train-station bureaucrats were still waiting for the memo about the USSR's demise. But I hope the city embraces its flying bear concept. ç Stay weird.
